entry.title: That‚Äôs enough, I‚Äôm starting a¬†blog
entry.content:
I‚Äôm tired of myself.

You see, I am a failed perfectionist. My brain is constantly between two sides of a weird spectrum: Either I am concentrating on tiny little details for way too long or I have no interest in a project whatsoever. I can spend hours fine-tuning a config file to then leave the project with no functionality.

This is the reason I haven‚Äôt started a blog until now. I was spending hours after hours trying to craft the perfect page layout and style, up to the point that I didn‚Äôt want to blog anything. A few weeks, or months, later I‚Äôd return to the project to then find the style I made back in the day not what I want ‚Äî and yet again I‚Äôm redoing the whole CSS instead of , well, writing.

Well, screw this. This is my blog now. Writing is now priority number one for me.

If I‚Äôll ever want to play around with the style, I can. I will, for that matter. But it‚Äôs important that I never lose my ability to write. The site may look ugly now, but I assure you this will change (sooner or later).

And while I‚Äôm at it: This is post 001 of #100DaysToOffload. Let‚Äôs get this started, shall we?

entry.title: Beginner‚Äôs Guide to¬†Inbox¬†Zero
entry.content:
Note: this article was initally written in Russian for my Telegram blog. You can read the original here.

Ways to effectively declutter my life become bigger of interest to me as I get older. I started to get more convinced that organization and minimalism do lead to greater efficiency and contribute to a more pleasant life.

There are many ways to bring organization into your life‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääby doing a KonMari-style clean-up, putting events into calendars or tracking every second of your time. Sometimes it can be difficult to get started, and it‚Äôs difficult to incorporate yourself into this system. But, as you know, you have to start small, and today I‚Äôm going to tell you about this ‚Äúsmall‚Äù.

Ideologyüîó

The name ‚ÄúInbox Zero‚Äù speaks for itself: the goal is to achieve an empty mailbox. As frightening as it may sound, it makes lots of sense.

I‚Äôve seen the mailboxes of many of my relatives and friends, and I was amazed each time at the number of emails that had long exceeded the mark of a thousand messages and their reaction to it: ‚ÄúCome on, I don‚Äôt use email anyway.‚Äù

Of course, this is rather true, and in the era of messengers, only a few people would want to invite a friend to a film via email. But, as sad as it may be, a lot of really important messages come to us via email. Developers get notifications about scheduled server shutdowns, students get news about courses and exams. The status of visa issuance and passport replacement, a dispute with an online store, and even promo-codes for pizza delivery‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall this ends up in our mailboxes. And these messages, which may be critical to the recipient, are lost in a huge flow of unnecessary and unsorted information.

There is only one way out of this‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääfiltering. But how do you filter a thousand already piled up emails? And how can you be sure that a deleted letter will not come in handy years later?

Action planüîó

Foreword. Archive &¬†Snoozeüîó

Before you get horrified at the thought of deleting your e-mails‚Ää‚Äî‚Äärelax. We‚Äôre not going to delete emails‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääinstead they will go to the Archive.

The Archive is just a folder with letters along with your Inbox. The Archive folder is provided in many email services and email clients, and some of them even have a separate button or gesture for quick archiving of messages.

If you do not have this feature in your email service/client, then 1) you have the wrong email service/client, and 2) do not get discouraged and just create a separate folder called ‚ÄúArchive‚Äù.

Another convenient feature would be Snooze‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääan opportunity to postpone the letter until some time later. The letter disappears from the Inbox and reappears at the scheduled time. Unfortunately, almost none of the services have implemented this feature at the moment, and we can only hope for email clients.

Step 1. Watch It¬†Burn!üîó

Didn‚Äôt somebody say they didn‚Äôt even read emails? Okay, well, let‚Äôs press ‚ÄúSelect All‚Äù and ‚ÄúArchive.‚Äù See that empty mailbox? Get used to it, it‚Äôll be your goal for the rest of your life. Of course, mass cleaning once every few days is not enough to keep things organized and clean. There are certain rules to follow.

Step 2. Notificationsüîó

In order to control your mailbox, you have to keep up to date with the events in it. Let‚Äôs turn on the notifications for new emails on our devices. Don‚Äôt worry, if a huge number of missed checkboxes cause your mail to fill up with unwanted emails from websites‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyou will have to get rid of this too. It‚Äôs better to choose the least annoying sound so that you don‚Äôt get sick of it over the next month.

Step 3. You‚Äôve Got¬†Mail!üîó

Here, as in the previous paragraphs, most of the time I will talk about what other ‚Äúambassadors‚Äù of the ideology have told before me, in particular about what should be done when a new email comes.

Is this an important person? Then answer the letter immediately. If you don‚Äôt have time, write a short reply saying ‚ÄúHi, I read your letter, but I can‚Äôt reply now, I‚Äôll do it later‚Äù. The sender will not remain in the dark and will know that you have not ignored his request. In the meantime, you shall snooze the letter to remember about it later. Did you reply, or was it not required from the start? To the Archive.

Is this a necessary newsletter? Read it. If there‚Äôs no time, snooze it. After reading it, archive it. If you wish to save something for a longer period of time, email was not created for that. Pay attention to the bookmarking services, such as Pocket or Instapaper.

Is this an unnecessary newsletter? Scroll to the end of the email and click ‚ÄúUnsubscribe‚Äù. The process is different for each site‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämake sure that all the checkboxes are ticked in your favour. After all these actions, the email should be deleted‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädo not clutter up the archive.

Is this a promo code? I had a tantrum with letters like that at first. It‚Äôs a necessary newsletter that I would like to keep for the future, but not long enough to clutter up the bookmarker. For promo codes, I have invented my own workflow. The promo code from the letter is to be moved to a note-taking app, where it is tagged correspondingly‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää‚Äú#promocode‚Äù. The letter is deleted or archived if it contains an important link. A reminder is placed on the note, which will be displayed on the last day of the code validity. If I haven‚Äôt used this code at all, the note shall be deleted on the last day.

Epilogueüîó

After a month of careful email revision, you may feel that the mailbox has become less scary, the emails do not come so often, and the messages themselves are necessary and interesting. In the end, your ‚Äúinbox‚Äù can become a cosy and pleasant world with its own traditions and customs.

And lastlyüîó

Why do I consider Inbox Zero the easiest step towards minimalism, organization, and efficiency? The answer is simple: it is the only step I have been able to take so far. While I‚Äôm trying to get used to the Pomodoro timers, good sleeping habits, KonMari and asceticism, my mailbox is empty and fresh.

Unless you look inside my spam folder, of course.

entry.title: How to¬†build TCP packets from scratch in¬†Python¬†3
entry.content:
One of¬†the assignments I¬†got at¬†my¬†university‚Äôs IT¬†Security classes was to¬†write a¬†small Python script that would create and send an¬†empty TCP packet with specified flags to¬†the desired host and port combo. This could be¬†easily achieved with scapy, but here‚Äôs the catch ‚Äî we¬†weren‚Äôt allowed to¬†use external dependencies for this assignment.

Building the packet itself didn‚Äôt cause problems, but checksum¬†did. I¬†searched the entire WWW to¬†find answers, but the only thing I¬†found was some spaghetti code that didn‚Äôt work (at¬†least in¬†Python¬†3). So¬†I¬†decided to¬†tear down scapy and create a¬†lightweight solution to¬†this exact issue.

Let‚Äôs get down to¬†business!

Building the packetüîó

Let‚Äôs create a¬†class TCPPacket, which will hold all the needed packet fields. I¬†will omit the¬†options and data fields.

class TCPPacket:
    def __init__(self,
                 src_host:  str,
                 src_port:  int,
                 dst_host:  str,
                 dst_port:  int,
                 flags:     int = 0):
        self.src_host = src_host
        self.src_port = src_port
        self.dst_host = dst_host
        self.dst_port = dst_port
        self.flags = flags

Let‚Äôs define the build function that will take those fields and encode them into a¬†long bytes sequence.

def build(self) -> bytes:
    packet = struct.pack(
        '!HHIIBBHHH',
        self.src_port,  # Source Port
        self.dst_port,  # Destination Port
        0,              # Sequence Number
        0,              # Acknoledgement Number
        5 << 4,         # Data Offset
        self.flags,     # Flags
        8192,           # Window
        0,              # Checksum (initial value)
        0               # Urgent pointer
    )

Here, I¬†use the built-in module struct. Notice how the Data Offset field is¬†offset (no¬†pun intended) by¬†four bits ‚Äî this is¬†done because, according to¬†the TCP spec, it¬†only takes the first four bits of¬†the byte, while the rest is¬†reserved.

The Checksum field should be¬†left at¬†0 for now, since it¬†will be¬†calculated later. The other constant parameters can be¬†changed to¬†your liking.

Calculating the checksumüîó

We¬†start by¬†composing a¬†function that will calculate our checksum. The spec tells us¬†the following:

The checksum field is¬†the 16 bit one‚Äôs complement of¬†the one‚Äôs complement sum of¬†all 16 bit words in¬†the header and text.

I¬†don‚Äôt know about you, but I¬†didn‚Äôt understand it¬†even after I‚Äôve read it¬†for the twentieth time. So¬†instead I¬†referred to¬†scapy‚Äôs source code and this is¬†what I‚Äôve composed:

def chksum(packet: bytes) -> int:
    if len(packet) % 2 != 0:
        packet += b'\0'

    res = sum(array.array("H", packet))
    res = (res >> 16) + (res & 0xffff)
    res += res >> 16

    return (~res) & 0xffff

This method makes use of¬†Python‚Äôs built-in array module, that creates an¬†array with fixed element types. This lets us¬†calculate the sum of¬†16-bit words more easily than using a¬†loop. Then the function simply applies some bit arithmetic magic to¬†the sum and returns it.

Before we¬†can apply this method to¬†our packet, we¬†need to¬†prepend it¬†with a¬†pseudo-header, that contains extra information, such as¬†IP¬†Addresses and TCP Length. Let‚Äôs head back to¬†the build() method and compose the pseudo-header:

pseudo_hdr = struct.pack(
    '!4s4sHH',
    socket.inet_aton(self.src_host),    # Source Address
    socket.inet_aton(self.dst_host),    # Destination Address
    socket.IPPROTO_TCP,                 # PTCL
    len(packet)                         # TCP Length
)

Please note that TCP Length should also include the length of¬†data sent with the packet. In¬†our case, the data is¬†empty, so¬†we¬†just use the header length.

After composing the pseudo-header, we¬†only need to¬†calculate the checksum and insert it¬†back into the packet:

checksum = chksum(pseudo_hdr + packet)

packet = packet[:16] + struct.pack('H', checksum) + packet[18:]

Make sure that the checksum is¬†inserted using the native byte order and not big-endian; this is¬†why there is¬†no¬†exclamation point in¬†the first argument of¬†struct.pack().

In¬†my¬†example, I¬†simply cut the packet in¬†between and insert the checksum. You can also build the packet from scratch using three consecutive struct.pack calls.

The packet is¬†finished, don‚Äôt forget to return it:

return packet

Sending the packetüîó

Now let‚Äôs make use of¬†the class we¬†just made and send a¬†TCP Packet. For example, this is¬†how we¬†would create a¬†Christmas Tree Packet (a¬†packet with FIN, URG and PSH flags):

dst = '192.168.1.1'

pak = TCPPacket(
    '192.168.1.42',
    20,
    dst,
    666,
    0b000101001  # Merry Christmas!
)

To¬†send this packet, we¬†need to¬†create a¬†socket connection using the TCP protocol:

s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_RAW, socket.IPPROTO_TCP)

This will add the required IP¬†header for us, so¬†we¬†don‚Äôt need to¬†bother building it¬†ourselves.

And finally, we¬†send the built packet using the¬†sendto() method:

s.sendto(pak.build(), (dst, 0))

The full code (licensed under the GNU¬†GPL 3.0) is¬†available as¬†a¬†GitHub Gist. In¬†conclusion, I‚Äôd like to¬†thank the developers of¬†scapy for being my, umm, ‚Äòinspiration‚Äô ;)
